text:
I'm curious if anyone has resources to share on aligning a content strategy around the customer journey.

Context: my career started in content marketing in the times when the only mature content strategies being talked about were SEO :smile: I experienced real content chaos when it came to later stage content -- "sales needs this asset right now!" and then you make it and everyone forgets about it in 2 months.

I feel hesitancy in jumping back into later stage content production that doesn't have a clear distribution plan. Later stage content is typically sent by SDR/BDRs or Sales Director / Account Exec type people. What is the recent thinking on how to prioritize, produce, manage, and distribute this type of content? :pray:

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text:
I'm curious if anyone has resources to share on aligning a content strategy around the customer journey.

Context: my career started in content marketing in the times when the only mature content strategies being talked about were SEO

I experienced real content chaos when it came to later stage content -- "sales needs this asset right now!" and then you make it and everyone forgets about it in 2 months.

I feel hesitancy in jumping back into later stage content production that doesn't have a clear distribution plan. Later stage content is typically sent by SDR/BDRs or Sales Director / Account Exec type people. What is the recent thinking on how to prioritize, produce, manage, and distribute this type of content?

text:
I don’t blame you for hesitating to create content that is only going to be distributed by sales, especially if there’s no good way to measure that distribution.

Personally I’m a fan of stage-based nurture programs in the sales cycle as well as once someone becomes a customer. It makes the content self-serve and doesn’t require a human to send it. Those roles should definitely be aware of what’s being sent (documentation helps), but that kind of manual effort really falls apart at scale.

elements.text:
I don’t blame you for hesitating to create content that is only going to be distributed by sales, especially if there’s no good way to measure that distribution.

Personally I’m a fan of stage-based nurture programs in the sales cycle as well as once someone becomes a customer. It makes the content self-serve and doesn’t require a human to send it. Those roles should definitely be aware of what’s being sent (documentation helps), but that kind of manual effort really falls apart at scale.

text: So the thinking flips from “what does sales need?” to “what does the customer need?”

elements.text: So the thinking flips from “what does sales need?” to “what does the customer need?”

text: For users, in-app promotions can also be an underutilized channel for content.

elements.text: For users, in-app promotions can also be an underutilized channel for content.

text: Also on a small team! I always try to utilize content I make for more than one thing to make the most of my efforts. For example, part of our social strategy is creating posts optimized for our social audience from the content that's written in a blog article. We can then link to the article in our linkinbio. Or, we write a blog article as a "journalistic" recap/promotion of a podcast episode we released and can link to that article in the show notes.

elements.text: Also on a small team! I always try to utilize content I make for more than one thing to make the most of my efforts. text:
1. Flexibility in writing (short, long, SEO, CRM, brand, sales, quick turn, long-term strategy, etc.)
2. Proactive in collaboration (contributes their ideas prompted and unprompted without holding them too precious)
3. Proactive in being on top of their work—I don't have to check to make sure a random thing that came up in a meeting got done.

elements.text: Flexibility in writing (short, long, SEO, CRM, brand, sales, quick turn, long-term strategy, etc.)
Proactive in collaboration (contributes their ideas prompted and unprompted without holding them too precious)
Proactive in being on top of their work—I don't have to check to make sure a random thing that came up in a meeting got done.

text: I'm working on our first-ever content strategy and am setting KPIs and goals. I'm wondering how to set benchmarks for content we'll be publishing on Medium when we have no prior data to look at. Is it best to look at competitor #s? Start small? Thoughts?

elements.text: I'm working on our first-ever content strategy and am setting KPIs and goals. I'm wondering how to set benchmarks for content we'll be publishing on Medium when we have no prior data to look at. Is it best to look at competitor #s? Start small? Thoughts?

text: <@U02QWSD3BSM> it depends on your budget and the level you're recruiting/hiring at... I would expect them all to be reasonably developed in a more seasoned person (obviously still over-indexing on some and under-indexing on others.) However, if you're looking for entry level/affordable/less experience, you'll certainly have to pick and choose, and be willing to train and mentor. In that case, a lot of the time you're judging "the lights are on" potential and culture fit a whole lot more... I generally like to hire people who have a growth mindset so are excited to learn things they haven't done before (and in fact get bored if it's all just rinse & repeat work). It also comes with the nature of digital marketing... the tools, tactics change all the time...

text:
This might not be the best approach, but I would work backwards from the end goal. What's the goal of this content?

For example, if it's product signups, then work backwards from how many signups you want to drive per month.

I'm curious as to why you're choosing to publish on Medium vs an owned blog though?

elements.text:

I'm curious as to why you're choosing to publish on Medium vs an owned blog though?

text:
We will be launching our own blog on our website in July, but it's taking a bit more time than we anticipated and we are eager to get our own content published before then as we're launching a rebrand soon.

Our goal is thought leadership versus sign ups, but interesting point re working backwards!

text:
<@UJG12DM1V> An approach I've been taking is mapping out content topics to the different stages of the buying journey via a "Jobs-To-Be-Done". In other words - I try to understand what prospects are looking for during the evaluation phase.

I've also built out messaging frameworks (similar to battle cards) but it's more of an "a la cart" or swipe file approach. This way after an SDR or AE has a discovery call  - they can tailor a follow-up email with the best data points and content to help the prospect make the best decision.

elements.text:

text:
I have been trying to understand how to use Twitter to increase brand awareness. Working for a SaaS startup, with a small following currently. We're trying to increase both our follower base and engagement on the platform.

Twitter feels trickier than the other social channels, probably because of the limits it puts on text etc.

I've looked up some articles on the topic, but still feel learning from the actual experience of marketers would be more worthwhile.

Any actionable tips/suggestions?

elements.text:

I've looked up some articles on the topic, but still feel learning from the actual experience of marketers would be more worthwhile.

Any actionable tips/suggestions?
A good thread to read

text:
I used to the below things in my last role at Automate. io

• Use this tool - Talkwalker. It basically gives you email notification whenever your brand gets tagged on Twitter.  Add competitor twitter handles in the Talkwalker so whenever someone talks about your competitor you can check that Tweet and respond to them. You can use some Hashtags as well in Talkwalker I guess. 
• Create a process where the system sends an automated message to anyone who follows your page. (I used <http://automate.io|automate.io> for this. You can use Zapier and a lot of other tools too.)  Along with DM, there are a few more options that you can play with. Like send automated comments to people who mentioned you etc. 
• Create a list of hashtags in your business niche and keep an eye on people who use those hashtags frequently. Once you get that data, reach out to them and ask if they can promote your product/business/blog/etc. Kind of influencer marketing strategy.

for this. You can use Zapier and a lot of other tools too.)  Along with DM, there are a few more options that you can play with. Like send automated comments to people who mentioned you etc.

Create a list of hashtags in your business niche and keep an eye on people who use those hashtags frequently. Once you get that data, reach out to them and ask if they can promote your product/business/blog/etc. Kind of influencer marketing strategy.
